summary: This is a DOJ OIG interview transcript of a Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant who was the Special Housing Unit (SHU) Lieutenant at MCC New York during the period leading up to Jeffrey Epstein's death. The interview focuses on the lieutenant's knowledge of policies, procedures, and communications regarding Epstein's housing requirements, specifically the mandate that he have a cellmate after returning from suicide watch. The lieutenant asserts that this requirement was widely known, communicated verbally and via posted notes, and that staff should have acted when Epstein was found alone.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate whose death in the SHU at MCC New York is the subject of the OIG investigation. The interview discusses his housing, suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, and the requirement that he have a cellmate.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: Inmate who was vetted and assigned as Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate in the SHU after Epstein returned from suicide watch. He was taken to court on August 9, 2019, and did not return.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Inmate who was briefly housed with Jeffrey Epstein in the SHU. An incident occurred between them on July 23, 2019, which the lieutenant recalls involved a suicide attempt by Epstein.

persons.name: Thomas
persons.context: Correctional Officer working in the SHU on the morning watch shift (midnight to 8 a.m.) on August 9-10, 2019. The interview discusses whether he received quarterly training and his actions upon finding Epstein.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: Correctional Officer working in the SHU on the morning watch shift (midnight to 8 a.m.) on August 9-10, 2019, alongside Officer Thomas.

persons.name: Collado
persons.context: An Officer in Charge (OIC) in the SHU who was injured and out sick prior to the events of August 2019.

persons.name: Dennis

connections.description: Reyes was vetted and assigned as Epstein's cellmate in the SHU after Epstein returned from suicide watch, in compliance with BOP policy.
Tartaglione was briefly housed with Epstein in the SHU prior to the July 23 incident, which the lieutenant recalls as a suicide attempt by Epstein.
Correctional Officers Thomas and Noel were partnered on the morning watch shift in the SHU on August 9-10, 2019.
Officer Thomas was one of the officers who found Epstein deceased and made the decision to enter the cell alone in an attempt to save him.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Attempt in SHU
events.description: An incident occurred between Jeffrey Epstein and his then-cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione. The lieutenant recalls it as a suicide attempt by Epstein, after which Epstein was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Returns to SHU with Cellmate Requirement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned to the SHU from suicide watch. Psychology and executive management mandated that he must have a cellmate. This was communicated via email and verbally, and notes were posted in the SHU.

events.title: Epstein's Cellmate Removed
events.description: Efrain Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, was taken to court and did not return to MCC New York, leaving Epstein without a cellmate in violation of the standing requirement.

events.title: Epstein Found Deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased in his SHU cell at MCC New York. Officers Thomas and Noel were on duty. Thomas entered the cell upon finding him.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview of BOP Lieutenant
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with the BOP Lieutenant who was the SHU Lieutenant in the period leading up to Epstein's death.

locations: 6 West 23rd Street, Deer Park, New York (Interview location)
MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York
10 South Lower / G Tier (Part of SHU for high-profile or disruptive inmates)
keyFacts: The BOP Lieutenant, as SHU Lieutenant, stated it was BOP policy and common knowledge that inmates returning from suicide watch must have a cellmate. This was communicated for Epstein via email, verbal instructions, and posted notes in the SHU.
The lieutenant was not on duty on August 9-10, 2019. He last saw Epstein alive on August 8 and stated Epstein was alive and had a cellmate (Efrain Reyes) when he left.
The lieutenant expressed strong personal belief that Epstein died by suicide, stating "Nobody killed that man. He did it himself."

The interview reveals potential procedural failures: a midnight count slip showed an incorrect inmate count for the SHU (73 instead of 72), and the lieutenant indicated staff should have noticed Epstein was alone during rounds or when he was escorted back to his cell after attorney visits.

The lieutenant defended Officer Thomas's decision to enter Epstein's cell alone upon finding him, citing emergency policy that allows entry to save a life without waiting for a supervisor or a second officer.
